Christopher Slobogin believes there should be a narrower definition of the insanity defense.

And how would you change the way the insanity defense is currently applied?
Well, I'm not against giving exculpatory effect to people with mental disability.
But my problem with current insanity tests, that, as was just mentioned, has to do with an inability to appreciate that the act was wrong or an inability to control behavior.
The problem with those tests is, if they're read literally, they excuse far too many people.
If you take the Fritzl case, for instance, it could easily be said that he didn't appreciate the wrongfulness of his conduct.
He may have even thought it was OK to do what he was doing.
And he might also be able to say, honestly, he felt strong urges to commit the act.
But the same can be said with respect to many people who commit crimes.
And it's not enough to say that most criminals do not have mental disorder.
Because, given the broad definition of that term, many people who do horrible things can be said to have a bonafide mental disorder.
So what I would do is, instead, change the focus of the inquiry in these cases to what the precise reasons for acting were.
And so what I would do, for instance, is compare people with mental illness to people who are not mentally disabled.
A person who is not mentally disabled, who thinks he's acting in self-defense, should have a defense.
I think all of us agree with that.
And I would argue, so should a person with mental disability.
Even if it turns out that because of his delusions, he has misperceived the situation.

So, as is often the case, including with the du Pont case that Professor Dershowitz mentioned a little bit earlier, if a mentally ill person thinks his victim is out to hurt him, he should have a defense.
But what if he thinks, like the Son of Sam, that he's getting instructions from his neighbor's dog?
Somebody else told him to do it?
That - based on what I know of that case, he would not have a defense.
And, in fact, Son of Sam was not found insane, which I think suggests that juries are more in line with what I'm suggesting than what the literal language of the insanity test reads like.
Going to the John Hinckley case, as another example, there supposedly, even if you believe the defense, his belief was that, if he killed Reagan, Jodie Foster would fall in love with him.
Even if you believe that to be true, that's not a justifiable reason for killing someone, no matter how mentally disordered he may have been.

Only if you believe the defense, which claim that killed her children to make sure they went to heaven, rather than hell, would she possibly have an excuse under the approach that I'm advocating?
So this would narrow the application.
